quoteFirst: This time she used Swedish colours, and called herself the _Dag_. On this voyage, whilst in the vicinity north of the North Hinder Bank, on April 4,
quoteLast: , a submarine was seen on the port bow, but disappeared.
title: Q-Ships and Their Story
author: Chatterton, E. Keble (Edward Keble), 1878-1944

quoteFirst: The men had a drop of rum when we got back, and it was
quoteLast: when I crawled into my flea bag. A family of beetles played, “Come and sit on my chair” across my toes, and an old brown rat wanted to keep me company.
title: A Soldier's Diary
author: Scott, Ralph

quoteFirst: On the 1st he sets at 7:26 p. m.; on the 15th rises at 4:44 a. m.; and on the 30th rises at
quoteLast: Is in conjunction with and 5° 8′ north of the moon at 2:36 on the morning of the 20th.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: High wind, cloudy but no rain all day; have moved my tent down by the men's, so am quite comfortable to-night. The officer of the day came along
quoteLast: ; all was quiet along the line during the night. The countersign is "Mexico." My rations are getting very short.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteFirst: Headquarters
quoteLast: , and then set out again at 4.30 to follow the battle and note and report the doings of our Willies.”
title: The Tank Corps
author: Williams-Ellis, Clough, 1883-1978; Williams-Ellis, Amabel, 1894-1984; Elles, Hugh Jamieson, 1880-1945 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: _June 22nd._--This morning Captain Radcliffe's troop of volunteer cavalry were despatched, at 1 A.M., towards Nawab Gunge, to patrol the roads in that direction, in conjunction with the Seikhs, in order to gather information.
quoteLast: a thunderstorm from the east, with the much wished for rain, came on. It lasted no very long time, and afforded only a temporary relief from the excessive heat.
title:
The Defence of Lucknow
A Diary Recording the Daily Events during the Siege of the European Residency, from 31st May to 25th September, 1857
author: Wilson, T. F. (Thomas Fourness)

quoteFirst: At this time we were crossing from the Las Vegas to the Muddy. I think the distance without water was sixty-five miles, so there was no alternative for us but to press forward to the Muddy River, were we arrived in safety
quoteLast: , watered our stock, and got a hasty meal, giving our animals a very short time for rest and to feed.
title: Life of a Pioneer: Being the Autobiography of James S. Brown
author: Brown, James S. (James Stephens), 1828-1902

quoteFirst: A shower of rain at sunset brought out legions of mosquitoes, from which, not having brought curtains, we suffered a good deal of annoyance, and the intolerable stench of the drain near which we lay was so increased by the rain that we had to smoke incessantly till past 3 a.m., almost regretting we had not accepted the barkeeper’s offer of the billiard-table for a bed. Even the “circus gentlemen” would have been preferable to the sewer. We got to sleep
quoteLast: , only to be awoke at daybreak by a crashing sound and to find the water rushing into the boat, with an unpleasant conviction that our craft was heeling over at a very uncomfortable angle. We had become entangled in the hawser of a large ocean-steamer, which, had it not been let go in the nick of time, would have upset us altogether.
title: From Pekin to Calais by Land
author: De Windt, Harry, 1856-1933

quoteFirst: There was so much broken ice on the inner side of it, that it reminded one of some of the pictures of the arctic voyages. We forced our vessel through--a little Indian river-boat--and found on the outside enough sea to make us very glad when we reached the 'Ferooz' at 2.30 A.M. It was
quoteLast: when I was able to lie down to rest. Since then we have been waiting for Parkes, who stayed at Tientsin for a letter from Pekin about the opening of the Yangtze river, which I am anxious to take with me to Shanghae. ...
title: Letters and Journals of James, Eighth Earl of Elgin
author: Elgin, James Bruce, Earl of, 1811-1863

quoteFirst: Varney read the announcement with a faint smile, glanced again at his watch, which stood at
quoteLast: , and dropped the letter into the box.
title: The shadow of the Wolf
author: Freeman, R. Austin (Richard Austin), 1862-1943

quoteFirst: It must have been
quoteLast: when Susi heard Majwara’s step once more.
title:
Stanley's Story; Or, Through the Wilds of Africa
A Thrilling Narrative of His Remarkable Adventures, Terrible Experiences, Wonderful Discoveries and Amazing Achievements in the Dark Continent
author: Feather, A. G., Col.

quoteFirst: Personally I crept up to a stump so close that I could hear the enemy hard at work, pulling down houses, cutting with axes, and building intrenchments.  I could almost hear their words, and I was thus listening when,
quoteLast: the bugler in the rebel camp sounded as pretty a reveille as I ever listened to.
title: Memoirs of General William T. Sherman — Volume 1
author: Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891

quoteFirst: "We had breakfast at 3 a.m. and I went to bed
quoteLast: I rose at 12 this morning. At breakfast we learnt some very good news. To-morrow we are leaving here and going into rest billets a long way behind the line for some time. Everybody is very happy indeed about it; I think we shall have a fine time there. So you have absolutely nothing to worry about now for quite a long time....
title: At Ypres with Best-Dunkley
author: Floyd, Thomas Hope, 1896-1973

quoteFirst: The guests were all more or less intoxicated by midnight, and kept on coming in in relays to look at us, as we lay feigning sleep, throughout the night. They did not break up till
quoteLast: , after obliging us with “Volga,” the boat-song I have mentioned, at the top of their voices, and all in different keys. It was past ten o’clock next morning before the fumes of the vodka had sufficiently evaporated to enable the fuddled post-master to produce a troika.
title: From Pekin to Calais by Land
author: De Windt, Harry, 1856-1933

quoteFirst: But before the torch had been put to a single building by Sherman's order, the smouldering fires set by Hampton were rekindled by the wind and communicated to the buildings around. About dark the flames began to spread, and were soon beyond the control of the brigade on duty in the town. An entire division was now brought in, but it was found impossible to check the conflagration, which by midnight had become quite unmanageable. It raged till
quoteLast: on the 18th, when the wind subsided, and the flames were got under control. … Beauregard, meanwhile, and the rebel cavalry, had retreated upon Charlotte, in North Carolina, due north from Columbia; and on the 20th and 21st Sherman followed as far as Winnsboro.
title: History for ready reference, Volumes 1 to 5
author: Larned, J. N. (Josephus Nelson), 1836-1913

quoteFirst: M., 19th Regiment, aged seventeen, of sanguine temperament, healthy frame, was brought up to camp
quoteLast: Sept. 9th, 1855. He had been wounded in the assault upon the Redan in the upper part of the left thigh, and had been lying by the side of the ditch where he fell thirteen hours. When discovered, he was carried carefully in a soldier’s greatcoat as far as the opening of the trenches, and thence on a stretcher to camp. He was very cold and prostrate on his arrival.
title: A Treatise on Gunshot Wounds
author: Longmore, T. (Thomas), Sir, 1816-1895

quoteFirst: Petty, Tierney, George Ponsonby, and Fox censured Melville severely. Canning with his wonted brilliance, Castlereagh with the usual laboured infelicity, sought to strengthen the defence; but it had almost collapsed when,
quoteLast: of 9th April, Wilberforce arose. At once Pitt bent forward and sent an eager glance down the Treasury bench at his old friend; for the verdict of a conscientious and independent member at such a time is decisive.
title: William Pitt and the Great War
author: Rose, J. Holland (John Holland), 1855-1942

quoteLast: when I was able to lie down to rest. Since then we have been waiting for Parkes, who stayed at Tientsin for a letter from Pekin about the opening of the Yangtze river, which I am anxious to take with me to Shanghae. ...

quoteLast: the bugler in the rebel camp sounded as pretty a reveille as I ever listened to.
title: Memoirs of the Union's Three Great Civil War Generals

quoteFirst: Granada, where we arrived
quoteLast: The whole journey from Jaen takes about twenty hours _en route_. You might do it quicker without _Miquelites_, as it is a long pull (seventeen leagues) for men to walk in one day; thermometer at 3000, and up hill.
title: The letters of Richard Ford, 1797-1858
author: Ford, Richard, 1796-1858; Prothero, Rowland E. (Rowland Edmund), Baron Ernle, 1851-1937 [Editor]
